quoteFirst: After riding for about an hour, however, I began to find the time rather long. I looked at my watch. It was past
quoteLast: . We had started at nine, and, allowing an hour and a half to have been spent in finding the cattle, I had passed nearly three hours in my wild and unsuccessful hunt. I began to think that I must have got further from the plantation than I had as yet supposed.
title: Blackwood's Edinburgh Magazine — Volume 54, No. 337, November, 1843
author: Various

quoteFirst: The question was soon decided, for all there was of the town could be seen in a very short time.
quoteLast: he started back to the motor boat. At 5 o'clock, just as the sun was setting, he came to the bayou where the _Rambler_ had been anchored.
title: The River Motor Boat Boys on the Mississippi; Or, On the Trail to the Gulf
author: Gordon, Harry; Davis, J. Watson, 1870-1959 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: On the third night, the moon was on the wane, and had begun to rise later;
quoteLast: in the morning, possibly, she heard a loud burst of laughter and her father’s voice calling her:—
title: Les Misérables
author: Hugo, Victor, 1802-1885; Hapgood, Isabel Florence, 1850-1928 [Translator]

quoteFirst: _Monday morning, July 25._—From an early hour, all hands busily occupied discharging the cargo, heavily-laden boats following each other to the shore. At half-past
quoteLast: , the last boat pushes off, the steam-whistle is blown, and we sail away round the south point of Stromoe, shaping our course north-west through Hestoe Fiord. The coast of the islands is abrupt, mostly rising sheer from the sea; many basaltic columns, and a succession of wave-worn caves, in front of which countless sea-birds are flying, swimming and diving.
title: Pen and pencil sketches of Faröe and Iceland
author: Symington, Andrew James, 1825-1898; Linton, W. J. (William James), 1812-1897 [Illustrator]; Ólafur Pálsson, 1814-1876 [Translator]

quoteFirst: Here every inch was over virgin ground, and we had to do it blindly. That day we had a feeling of going downhill. At
quoteLast: land was reported right ahead. From the gesticulations of those in front I made out that it must be uncommonly big. I saw absolutely nothing, but that was not very surprising.
title: The South Pole; an account of the Norwegian Antarctic expedition in the "Fram," 1910-1912 — Volume 1
author: Amundsen, Roald, 1872-1928; Nansen, Fridtjof, 1861-1930 [Author of introduction, etc.]; Chater, Arthur G. (Arthur Grosvenor), 1866-1951 [Translator]

title: Nobody
author: Vance, Louis Joseph, 1879-1933; Jacobs, W. L. (William Leroy), 1869-1917 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: Chandos; now the remembrance of Lady Chandos's vexation at my being there. As
quoteLast: , I rose from my uneasy bed, determined to try what walking about the chamber would do. Pulling the blind aside, quietly opening the shutters, I paused to look out on the lovely night, its clear atmosphere and its shining stars nearly as bright as day.
title: Anne Hereford: A Novel
author: Wood, Henry, Mrs., 1814-1887

quoteFirst: The wailings came at less frequent intervals now, though they continued to be sufficiently awesome. But when the clock showed two minutes before
quoteLast: in the morning these words came in a blast:
title: The Grammar School Boys Snowbound; or, Dick & Co. at Winter Sports
author: Hancock, H. Irving (Harrie Irving), 1868-1922

quoteFirst: Mr. Wesley says that, on the night of the 21st of December, "I was wakened, a little before
quoteLast: , by nine distinct and very loud knocks, which seemed to be in the next room to ours, with a short pause at every third knock." The next night Emily heard knocks on the bedstead and under the bed. She knocked, and it answered her.
title: The Young People's Wesley
author: McDonald, W. (William), 1820-1901; Mallalieu, Willard F. (Willard Francis), 1828-1911 [Author of introduction, etc.]
